comment.narrative:
1.1.1. 16108 IDUs reached through trust points and community outreach
1.1.2. 6932 SW reached with HIV prevention services
1.1.3. 1180 MSM reached with HIV prevention services
1.1.4. 31703 young people reached by peer education
1.1.5. 7824 STI treatment courses provided in friendly cabinets
2.2.1.1. 3832 eligible HIV positive people receiving ARV treatment
2.2.1.2. 7405 OI treatment courses delivered
2.2.2. 3552 PLHIV and their family members benefiting from psycho social support
2.2.3. Medical staff requiring additional qualification to provide counseling and testing
2.2.4.1 Medical staff requiring additional training on PMTCT
2.2.4.2. 485/678 71.5% pregnant women who have received ARV prophylaxis to reduce MTCT
2.2.4.3. 481/520 91.5% of infants born to HIV positive mothers who received ART prophylaxis
3.3.1. National action plan on HIV/AIDS expired in 2011 (YY2006-2011)
3.3.2. insufficient level of knowledge on infection control among country epidemiologists (300 epidem. trained in infection control in 2011)
3.3.3. Absence of care standards on health services provision to HIV positive people
4.1.1.No network of NGOs that will enable civil society to actively participate in the process of combating HIV/AIDS
4.1.2.1. High level of stigma and discrimination against PLHIV in the society as well as among opinion makers.
4.1.2.2. Lack of commitment among policy makers and service providers at different levels to reduce stigma and discrimination against PLHIV and MARPS
5.1.1.1. Sentinel Surveillance conducted in the Y 2009
5.1.1.2. No electronic database for monitoring of HIV prevention, treatment programs and drug forecasting in the country
6.1.1.1 Medical staff requiring additional knowledge in infection control
6.1.1.2. 66.7% of health facilities meet the basic service capacity standards in infection control
6.1.2. Lab staff requiring knowledge in quality control
6.1.3.1. weak voluntary blood donation programs/systems
6.1.3.2. 82

1. 29,000 IDUs reached through trust points and community outreach 2. 12,600 SW reached with HIV prevention services 3. 1,500 MSM reached with HIV prevention services 4. 13250 of MARPs (IDUs, SWs, MSM) tested and counseled for HIV and who received test results 5. 10,000 of new STI treatment courses provided in friendly cabinets 6. 8325 of eligible HIV positive people receiving ARV treatment 7. 65% of adults and children newly enrolled in HIV care receiving isoniazid preventive therapy 8. 8000 of PLHIV and their family members benefiting from psycho social support 9. 582/600 and 97% of HIV positive pregnant women who have received ARV prophylaxis to reduce MTCT in accordance with nationally approved treatment protocol 10. 570/600 and 95% of infants born to HIV positive mothers who received ART prophylaxis 11. 75% of health facilities that meet the basic service capacity standards (in infection control) 12. 17/17 and 0.0% of health facilities dispensing antiretroviral therapy that have experienced a stock-out of at least one required antiretroviral drug in the last 12 months

Reporting for the period January 1 June 30, 2015 1. 25,157 IDUs reached through trust points and community outreach 2. 11,417 SW reached with HIV prevention services 3. 1420 MSM reached with HIV prevention services 4. 9833 of MARPs (IDUs, SWs, MSM) tested and counseled for HIV and who received test results 5. 6122 of new STI treatment courses provided in friendly cabinets 6. 7852 of eligible HIV positive people receiving ARV treatment 8. 5329 of PLHIV and their family members benefiting from psycho social support 9. 197/201 and 98% of HIV positive pregnant women who have received ARV prophylaxis to reduce MTCT in accordance with nationally approved treatment protocol 10. 255/262 and 97.3% of infants born to HIV positive mothers who received ART prophylaxis

description.narrative: The project is designed to support the improved, more sustainable and more resilient land use management of non- irrigated arid desert, steppe and mountain landscapes of Uzbekistan.
Reducing pressures on natural resources from competing land use in non-irrigated arid mountain, semi-desert and desert landscapes of Uzbekistan

To promote integrated management of rangeland and forests at the landscape level (focus on non-irrigated, arid mountain, semi-desert, and desert landscapes) to reduce pressures on natural resources from competing land uses and improve the socio-economic stability of communities.
Number of hectares of pastures, forest and rain-fed arable land in two target districts that are under improved management.

comment.narrative: Zero

11,000 hectares of improved forestries.
26,000 hectares of improved pastures.
2,000 hectares improved rainfed lands.
Long-term goal: at the replication rate of 2%, improved management will be introduced on 600,000 hectares of forests, 4 million hectares of pastures and 150,000 hectares of rainfed lands in 10 years
Currently areas under improved management include 18 ha of forest, 50 ha of pasture, 20 ha of rain-fed lands.

description.narrative: Promising best practices on sustainable rangeland and forestry management and INRM planning up-scaled in target districts of Uzbekistan.
Improvement or maintenance of vegetative cover in pilot sites in target districts

comment.narrative:
Maintenance in vegetative cover or improvement in cover over baseline by:
8% for pastureland;
6% for forestry; and
6% for rain-fed areas

description.narrative: Area of pasture classified as degraded in project sites

comment.narrative: 280,000 ha (95,000 ha Zaamin, 185,000 ha Karakul)
254,000 ha or less by year 5 (84,000 or less in Zaamin; 170,000 or less in Karakul)
Pasture degradation has reduced due to implementation of the project actions in first year: by 30 ha in Zamin and by 20 ha in Karakul

description.narrative: Area of pasture used by dekhans (households) under collaborative management (pasture user groups)

comment.narrative: Zero
300 hectares of pastures are jointly managed by two PUGs
N/A. Data will be obtained at the end of this year and reported in the next PIR.

description.narrative: Number of dekhans with formal legal rights (and obligations) for areas used as pasture

comment.narrative: Zero
At least 600 hectares will be managed based on contracts with shirkats by the 5th year of project implementation.
N/A. Data will be obtained at the end of the third year

description.narrative: Area of forest planted or managed through state and community collaborative mechanisms (JFM, community forests, collaborative moving sand fixation)

comment.narrative: Zero
Not less than 100 ha by year 5 (60 Zamin, 40 Karakul)
During the first year the project together with forestry entities and local communities of both pilot areas created two forest nurseries: 3 ha in Zamin and 2.5 ha in Karakul.

description.narrative: Humus content of rain-fed arable land in plough layer

comment.narrative: Average 16.7 t/ha
Improvement in humus content of 100 ha rain-fed arable in Zaamin district (16.7 t/ha) by year 5
N/A. Data will be obtained at the end of the third year.

description.narrative: Local small businesses involved in production or application of appropriate technologies

comment.narrative: None
5 businesses involved in production/services related to appropriate technology for reducing fuel wood demand, cost effective well pumping or renewable energy production by year 5

Business plans and necessary formal documents prepared for a vine garden and a shop for processing medical plants. Equipment, fencing and seed materials are purchased. Full assessment will be provided at the end of this year.

description.narrative: Number of livestock wells rehabilitated and adequately maintained in project sites

comment.narrative: Not more than 10
10 wells rebuilt by the 5th year of project implementation
N/A. Data will be obtained at the end of this year.

description.narrative: An enabling cross-sector environment and in-country capacity (at system, institutional and individual levels) for applying integrated landscape management in arid mountain, semi-desert and desert areas of Uzbekistan
National pasture use strategic policy/plan incorporating long term integrated sustainable pasture use objectives

comment.narrative: No mid/long term strategic development policy for pasture use in Uzbekistan
A mid/long term strategic policy for sustainable pasture use which provides a basis for legal and institutional reform
Concept for national strategy on land use improvement developed and concept of national program in the field of pasture and forestry area management drafted.

description.narrative: An up-to-date national forestry programme / plan supported by government that incorporates long term integrated sustainable use objectives

comment.narrative: National forestry programme prepared but lacks key components and full government commitment for implementation.
An updated national forestry programme/plan approved by government and has an allocated budget by year 5
Concept for national strategy on land use improvement developed and concept of national program in the field of forestry area management drafted.

description.narrative: A strategic policy/plan on rain-fed agriculture that incorporates long term integrated sustainable use objectives

comment.narrative: No such strategic plan
A strategic plan for the long term development of rain-fed arable agriculture and role in overall agricultural system by year 5
Concept for national strategy on land use improvement developed and concept of national program in the field of rain fed area management drafted.

description.narrative: Inter-ministerial mechanism for ensuring coordination of land use policies operating effectively

comment.narrative: Mechanism exists in principle
Inter-ministerial Coordinating Council has a clear mandate and method of operation to ensure coordination of different land use sectors by year 4
Progress on this indicator will be reporting in the next PIR.

description.narrative: Pasture legislation and tenure arrangements allow more effective pasture use and fully recognize household/dekhan pasture users

comment.narrative: No specific pasture use legislation, other legislation such as Land Code inadequate
Either a Pasture Law for Uzbekistan or adequate revisions to Land Code and other relevant legislation and normative documents completed by year 5
No progress this reporting period. Some activities will start at the end of this year and will be reported in the next PIR.

description.narrative: National and regional training institutions producing graduates with sound understanding of integrated land use concepts and approaches

comment.narrative: Current national and regional training institutions have outdated courses which poorly address sustainable land use issues, particularly of non-irrigated landscapes
At least 1 training institution at national level and 1 at regional level have strengthened curriculum that addresses sustainable land use planning, including in non-irrigated areas by year 5.
No progress this reporting period. Some activities will start at the end of this year and will be reported in the next PIR.
